trans-unit.source: Compute-intensive Java application on a VM | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Compute-intensive Java application on a VM | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to create an Azure virtual machine that runs a compute-intensive Java application that can be monitored by another Java application.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to create an Azure virtual machine that runs a compute-intensive Java application that can be monitored by another Java application.

trans-unit.source: How to run a compute-intensive task in Java on a virtual machine
trans-unit.target: How to run a compute-intensive task in Java on a virtual machine

trans-unit.source: With Azure, you can use a virtual machine to handle compute-intensive tasks.
trans-unit.target: With Azure, you can use a virtual machine to handle compute-intensive tasks.

trans-unit.source: For example, a virtual machine can handle tasks and deliver results to client machines or mobile applications.
trans-unit.target: For example, a virtual machine can handle tasks and deliver results to client machines or mobile applications.

trans-unit.source: After reading this article, you will have an understanding of how to create a virtual machine that runs a compute-intensive Java application that can be monitored by another Java application.
trans-unit.target: After reading this article, you will have an understanding of how to create a virtual machine that runs a compute-intensive Java application that can be monitored by another Java application.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial assumes you know how to create Java console applications, can import libraries to your Java application, and can generate a Java archive (JAR).
trans-unit.target: This tutorial assumes you know how to create Java console applications, can import libraries to your Java application, and can generate a Java archive (JAR).

trans-unit.source: No knowledge of Microsoft Azure is assumed.
trans-unit.target: No knowledge of Microsoft Azure is assumed.

trans-unit.source: You will learn:
trans-unit.target: You will learn:

trans-unit.source: How to create a virtual machine with a Java Development Kit (JDK) already installed.
trans-unit.target: How to create a virtual machine with a Java Development Kit (JDK) already installed.

trans-unit.source: How to remotely log in to your virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: How to remotely log in to your virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: How to create a service bus namespace.
trans-unit.target: How to create a service bus namespace.

trans-unit.source: How to create a Java application that performs a compute-intensive task.
trans-unit.target: How to create a Java application that performs a compute-intensive task.

trans-unit.source: How to create a Java application that monitors the progress of the compute-intensive task.
trans-unit.target: How to create a Java application that monitors the progress of the compute-intensive task.

trans-unit.source: How to run the Java applications.
trans-unit.target: How to run the Java applications.

trans-unit.source: How to stop the Java applications.
trans-unit.target: How to stop the Java applications.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial will use the Traveling Salesman Problem for the compute-intensive task.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial will use the Traveling Salesman Problem for the compute-intensive task.

trans-unit.source: The following is an example of the Java application running the compute-intensive task.
trans-unit.target: The following is an example of the Java application running the compute-intensive task.

trans-unit.source: Traveling Salesman Problem solver
trans-unit.target: Traveling Salesman Problem solver

trans-unit.source: The following is an example of the Java application monitoring the compute-intensive task.
trans-unit.target: The following is an example of the Java application monitoring the compute-intensive task.

trans-unit.source: Traveling Salesman Problem client
trans-unit.target: Traveling Salesman Problem client

trans-unit.source: To create a virtual machine
trans-unit.target: To create a virtual machine

trans-unit.source: Log in to the [Azure Management Portal](https://manage.windowsazure.com).
trans-unit.target: Log in to the [Azure Management Portal](https://manage.windowsazure.com).

trans-unit.source: Click **New**, click **Compute**, click **Virtual machine**, and then click **From Gallery**.
trans-unit.target: Click **New**, click **Compute**, click **Virtual machine**, and then click **From Gallery**.

trans-unit.source: In the **Virtual machine image select** dialog box, select **JDK 7 Windows Server 2012**.
trans-unit.target: In the **Virtual machine image select** dialog box, select **JDK 7 Windows Server 2012**.

trans-unit.source: Note that **JDK 6 Windows Server 2012** is available in case you have legacy applications that are not yet ready to run in JDK 7.
trans-unit.target: Note that **JDK 6 Windows Server 2012** is available in case you have legacy applications that are not yet ready to run in JDK 7.

trans-unit.source: Click **Next**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Next**.

trans-unit.source: In the **Virtual machine configuration** dialog box:
trans-unit.target: In the **Virtual machine configuration** dialog box:

trans-unit.source: Specify a name for the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: Specify a name for the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Specify the size to use for the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: Specify the size to use for the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Enter a name for the administrator in the **User Name** field.
trans-unit.target: Enter a name for the administrator in the **User Name** field.

trans-unit.source: Remember this name and the password you will enter next, you will use them when you remotely log in to the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: Remember this name and the password you will enter next, you will use them when you remotely log in to the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Enter a password in the **New password** field, and re-enter it in the **Confirm** field.
trans-unit.target: Enter a password in the **New password** field, and re-enter it in the **Confirm** field.

trans-unit.source: This is the Administrator account password.
trans-unit.target: This is the Administrator account password.

trans-unit.source: Click **Next**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Next**.

trans-unit.source: In the next **Virtual machine configuration** dialog box:
trans-unit.target: In the next **Virtual machine configuration** dialog box:

trans-unit.source: For **Cloud service**, use the default **Create a new cloud service**.
trans-unit.target: For **Cloud service**, use the default **Create a new cloud service**.

trans-unit.source: The value for **Cloud service DNS name** must be unique across cloudapp.net.
trans-unit.target: The value for **Cloud service DNS name** must be unique across cloudapp.net.

trans-unit.source: If needed, modify this value so that Azure indicates it is unique.
trans-unit.target: If needed, modify this value so that Azure indicates it is unique.

trans-unit.source: Specify a region, affinity group, or virtual network.
trans-unit.target: Specify a region, affinity group, or virtual network.

trans-unit.source: For purposes of this tutorial, specify a region such as **West US**.
trans-unit.target: For purposes of this tutorial, specify a region such as **West US**.

trans-unit.source: For **Storage Account**, select **Use an automatically generated storage account**.
trans-unit.target: For **Storage Account**, select **Use an automatically generated storage account**.

trans-unit.source: For **Availability Set**, select **(None)**.
trans-unit.target: For **Availability Set**, select **(None)**.

trans-unit.source: Click **Next**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Next**.

trans-unit.source: In the final **Virtual machine configuration** dialog box:
trans-unit.target: In the final **Virtual machine configuration** dialog box:

trans-unit.source: Accept the default endpoint entries.
trans-unit.target: Accept the default endpoint entries.

trans-unit.source: Click **Complete**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Complete**.

trans-unit.source: To remotely log in to your virtual machine
trans-unit.target: To remotely log in to your virtual machine

trans-unit.source: Log on to the [Management Portal](https://manage.windowsazure.com).
trans-unit.target: Log on to the [Management Portal](https://manage.windowsazure.com).

trans-unit.source: Click **Virtual machines**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Virtual machines**.

trans-unit.source: Click the name of the virtual machine that you want to log in to.
trans-unit.target: Click the name of the virtual machine that you want to log in to.

trans-unit.source: Click **Connect**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Connect**.

trans-unit.source: Respond to the prompts as needed to connect to the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: Respond to the prompts as needed to connect to the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: When prompted for the administrator name and password, use the values that you provided when you created the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: When prompted for the administrator name and password, use the values that you provided when you created the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Note that the Azure Service Bus functionality requires the Baltimore CyberTrust Root certificate to be installed as part of your JRE's **cacerts** store.
trans-unit.target: Note that the Azure Service Bus functionality requires the Baltimore CyberTrust Root certificate to be installed as part of your JRE's **cacerts** store.

trans-unit.source: This certificate is automatically included in the Java Runtime Environment (JRE) used by this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: This certificate is automatically included in the Java Runtime Environment (JRE) used by this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: If you do not have this certificate in your JRE **cacerts** store, see [Adding a Certificate to the Java CA Certificate Store][add_ca_cert] for information on adding it (as well as information on viewing the certificates in your cacerts store).
trans-unit.target: If you do not have this certificate in your JRE **cacerts** store, see [Adding a Certificate to the Java CA Certificate Store][add_ca_cert] for information on adding it (as well as information on viewing the certificates in your cacerts store).

trans-unit.source: How to create a service bus namespace
trans-unit.target: How to create a service bus namespace

trans-unit.source: To begin using Service Bus queues in Azure, you must first
trans-unit.target: To begin using Service Bus queues in Azure, you must first

trans-unit.source: create a service namespace.
trans-unit.target: create a service namespace.

trans-unit.source: A service namespace provides a scoping
trans-unit.target: A service namespace provides a scoping

trans-unit.source: container for addressing Service Bus resources within your application.
trans-unit.target: container for addressing Service Bus resources within your application.

trans-unit.source: To create a service namespace:
trans-unit.target: To create a service namespace:

trans-unit.source: Log on to the [Azure Management Portal](https://manage.windowsazure.com).
trans-unit.target: Log on to the [Azure Management Portal](https://manage.windowsazure.com).

trans-unit.source: In the lower-left navigation pane of the Management Portal, click **Service Bus, Access Control & Caching**.
trans-unit.target: In the lower-left navigation pane of the Management Portal, click **Service Bus, Access Control & Caching**.

trans-unit.source: In the upper-left pane of the Management Portal, click the **Service Bus** node, and then click the **New** button.
trans-unit.target: In the upper-left pane of the Management Portal, click the **Service Bus** node, and then click the **New** button.

trans-unit.source: ![Service Bus Node screenshot][svc_bus_node]
trans-unit.target: ![Service Bus Node screenshot][svc_bus_node]

trans-unit.source: In the **Create a new Service Namespace** dialog box, enter a
trans-unit.target: In the **Create a new Service Namespace** dialog box, enter a

trans-unit.source: **Namespace**, and then to make sure that it is unique, click the
trans-unit.target: **Namespace**, and then to make sure that it is unique, click the

trans-unit.source: **Check Availability** button.
trans-unit.target: **Check Availability** button.

trans-unit.source: ![Create a New Namespace screenshot][create_namespace]
trans-unit.target: ![Create a New Namespace screenshot][create_namespace]

trans-unit.source: After making sure the namespace name is available, choose the
trans-unit.target: After making sure the namespace name is available, choose the

trans-unit.source: country or region in which your namespace should be hosted, and then click the **Create Namespace** button.
trans-unit.target: country or region in which your namespace should be hosted, and then click the **Create Namespace** button.

trans-unit.source: The namespace you created will then appear in the Management Portal
trans-unit.target: The namespace you created will then appear in the Management Portal

trans-unit.source: and takes a moment to activate.
trans-unit.target: and takes a moment to activate.

trans-unit.source: Wait until the status is **Active** before continuing with the next step.
trans-unit.target: Wait until the status is **Active** before continuing with the next step.

trans-unit.source: Obtain the Default Management Credentials for the namespace
trans-unit.target: Obtain the Default Management Credentials for the namespace

trans-unit.source: In order to perform management operations, such as creating a queue, on
trans-unit.target: In order to perform management operations, such as creating a queue, on

trans-unit.source: the new namespace, you need to obtain the management credentials for the
trans-unit.target: the new namespace, you need to obtain the management credentials for the

trans-unit.source: namespace.
trans-unit.target: namespace.

trans-unit.source: In the left navigation pane, click the **Service Bus** node to
trans-unit.target: In the left navigation pane, click the **Service Bus** node to

trans-unit.source: display the list of available namespaces.
trans-unit.target: display the list of available namespaces.

trans-unit.source: ![Available Namespaces screenshot][avail_namespaces]
trans-unit.target: ![Available Namespaces screenshot][avail_namespaces]

trans-unit.source: Select the namespace you just created from the list shown.
trans-unit.target: Select the namespace you just created from the list shown.

trans-unit.source: Namespace List screenshot
trans-unit.target: Namespace List screenshot

trans-unit.source: The right-hand **Properties** pane lists the properties for the
trans-unit.target: The right-hand **Properties** pane lists the properties for the

trans-unit.source: new namespace.
trans-unit.target: new namespace.

trans-unit.source: ![Properties Pane screenshot][properties_pane]
trans-unit.target: ![Properties Pane screenshot][properties_pane]

trans-unit.source: The **Default Key** is hidden.
trans-unit.target: The **Default Key** is hidden.

trans-unit.source: Click the **View** button to display
trans-unit.target: Click the **View** button to display

trans-unit.source: the security credentials.
trans-unit.target: the security credentials.

trans-unit.source: ![Default Key screenshot][default_key]
trans-unit.target: ![Default Key screenshot][default_key]

trans-unit.source: Make a note of the **Default Issuer** and the **Default Key** as you
trans-unit.target: Make a note of the **Default Issuer** and the **Default Key** as you

trans-unit.source: will use this information below to perform operations with the
trans-unit.target: will use this information below to perform operations with the

trans-unit.source: namespace.
trans-unit.target: namespace.

trans-unit.source: How to create a Java application that performs a compute-intensive task
trans-unit.target: How to create a Java application that performs a compute-intensive task

trans-unit.source: On your development machine (which does not have to be the virtual machine that you created), download the [Azure SDK for Java](http://azure.microsoft.com/develop/java/).
trans-unit.target: On your development machine (which does not have to be the virtual machine that you created), download the [Azure SDK for Java](http://azure.microsoft.com/develop/java/).

trans-unit.source: Create a Java console application using the example code at the end of this section.
trans-unit.target: Create a Java console application using the example code at the end of this section.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, we'll use **TSPSolver.java** as the Java file name.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, we'll use **TSPSolver.java** as the Java file name.

trans-unit.source: Modify the **your\_service\_bus\_namespace**, **your\_service\_bus\_owner**, and **your\_service\_bus\_key** placeholders to use your service bus **namespace**, **Default Issuer** and **Default Key** values, respectively.
trans-unit.target: Modify the **your\_service\_bus\_namespace**, **your\_service\_bus\_owner**, and **your\_service\_bus\_key** placeholders to use your service bus **namespace**, **Default Issuer** and **Default Key** values, respectively.

trans-unit.source: After coding, export the application to a runnable Java archive (JAR), and package the required libraries into the generated JAR.
trans-unit.target: After coding, export the application to a runnable Java archive (JAR), and package the required libraries into the generated JAR.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, we'll use **TSPSolver.jar** as the generated JAR name.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, we'll use **TSPSolver.jar** as the generated JAR name.

trans-unit.source: How to create a Java application that monitors the progress of the compute-intensive task
trans-unit.target: How to create a Java application that monitors the progress of the compute-intensive task

trans-unit.source: On your development machine, create a Java console application using the example code at the end of this section.
trans-unit.target: On your development machine, create a Java console application using the example code at the end of this section.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, we'll use **TSPClient.java** as the Java file name.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, we'll use **TSPClient.java** as the Java file name.

trans-unit.source: As shown earlier, modify the **your\_service\_bus\_namespace**, **your\_service\_bus\_owner**, and **your\_service\_bus\_key** placeholders to use your service bus **namespace**, **Default Issuer** and **Default Key** values, respectively.
trans-unit.target: As shown earlier, modify the **your\_service\_bus\_namespace**, **your\_service\_bus\_owner**, and **your\_service\_bus\_key** placeholders to use your service bus **namespace**, **Default Issuer** and **Default Key** values, respectively.

trans-unit.source: Export the application to a runnable JAR, and package the required libraries into the generated JAR.
trans-unit.target: Export the application to a runnable JAR, and package the required libraries into the generated JAR.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, we'll use **TSPClient.jar** as the generated JAR name.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, we'll use **TSPClient.jar** as the generated JAR name.

trans-unit.source: How to run the Java applications
trans-unit.target: How to run the Java applications

trans-unit.source: Run the compute-intensive application, first to create the queue, then to solve the Traveling Saleseman Problem, which will add the current best route to the service bus queue.
trans-unit.target: Run the compute-intensive application, first to create the queue, then to solve the Traveling Saleseman Problem, which will add the current best route to the service bus queue.

trans-unit.source: While the compute-intensive application is running (or afterwards), run the client to display results from the service bus queue.
trans-unit.target: While the compute-intensive application is running (or afterwards), run the client to display results from the service bus queue.

trans-unit.source: To run the compute-intensive application
trans-unit.target: To run the compute-intensive application

trans-unit.source: Log on to your virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: Log on to your virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Create a folder where you will run your application.
trans-unit.target: Create a folder where you will run your application.

trans-unit.source: For example, **c:\TSP**.
trans-unit.target: For example, **c:\TSP**.

trans-unit.source: Copy **TSPSolver.jar** to **c:\TSP**,
trans-unit.target: Copy **TSPSolver.jar** to **c:\TSP**,

trans-unit.source: Create a file named **c:\TSP\cities.txt** with the following contents.
trans-unit.target: Create a file named **c:\TSP\cities.txt** with the following contents.

trans-unit.source: At a command prompt, change directories to c:\TSP.
trans-unit.target: At a command prompt, change directories to c:\TSP.

trans-unit.source: Ensure the JRE's bin folder is in the PATH environment variable.
trans-unit.target: Ensure the JRE's bin folder is in the PATH environment variable.

trans-unit.source: You'll need to create the service bus queue before you run the TSP solver permutations.
trans-unit.target: You'll need to create the service bus queue before you run the TSP solver permutations.

trans-unit.source: Run the following command to create the service bus queue.
trans-unit.target: Run the following command to create the service bus queue.

trans-unit.source: Now that the queue is created, you can run the TSP solver permutations.
trans-unit.target: Now that the queue is created, you can run the TSP solver permutations.

trans-unit.source: For example, run the following command to run the solver for 8 cities.
trans-unit.target: For example, run the following command to run the solver for 8 cities.

trans-unit.source: If you don't specify a number, it will run for 10 cities.
trans-unit.target: If you don't specify a number, it will run for 10 cities.

trans-unit.source: As the solver finds current shortest routes, it will add them to the queue.
trans-unit.target: As the solver finds current shortest routes, it will add them to the queue.

trans-unit.source: The larger the number that you specify, the longer the solver will run.
trans-unit.target: The larger the number that you specify, the longer the solver will run.

trans-unit.source: For example, running for 14 cities could take several minutes, and running for 15 cities could take several hours.
trans-unit.target: For example, running for 14 cities could take several minutes, and running for 15 cities could take several hours.

trans-unit.source: Increasing to 16 or more cities could result in days of runtime (eventually weeks, months, and years).
trans-unit.target: Increasing to 16 or more cities could result in days of runtime (eventually weeks, months, and years).

trans-unit.source: This is due to the rapid increase in the number of permutations evaluated by the solver as the number of cities increases.
trans-unit.target: This is due to the rapid increase in the number of permutations evaluated by the solver as the number of cities increases.

trans-unit.source: How to run the monitoring client application
trans-unit.target: How to run the monitoring client application

trans-unit.source: Log on to your machine where you will run the client application.
trans-unit.target: Log on to your machine where you will run the client application.

trans-unit.source: This does not need to be the same machine running the **TSPSolver** application, although it can be.
trans-unit.target: This does not need to be the same machine running the **TSPSolver** application, although it can be.

trans-unit.source: Create a folder where you will run your application.
trans-unit.target: Create a folder where you will run your application.

trans-unit.source: For example, **c:\TSP**.
trans-unit.target: For example, **c:\TSP**.

trans-unit.source: Copy **TSPClient.jar** to **c:\TSP**,
trans-unit.target: Copy **TSPClient.jar** to **c:\TSP**,

trans-unit.source: Ensure the JRE's bin folder is in the PATH environment variable.
trans-unit.target: Ensure the JRE's bin folder is in the PATH environment variable.

trans-unit.source: At a command prompt, change directories to c:\TSP.
trans-unit.target: At a command prompt, change directories to c:\TSP.

trans-unit.source: Run the following command.
trans-unit.target: Run the following command.

trans-unit.source: Optionally, specify the number of minutes to sleep in between checking the queue, by passing in a command-line argument.
trans-unit.target: Optionally, specify the number of minutes to sleep in between checking the queue, by passing in a command-line argument.

trans-unit.source: The default sleep period for checking the queue is 3 minutes, which is used if no command-line argument is passed to **TSPClient**.
trans-unit.target: The default sleep period for checking the queue is 3 minutes, which is used if no command-line argument is passed to **TSPClient**.

trans-unit.source: If you want to use a different value for the sleep interval, for example, one minute, run the following command.
trans-unit.target: If you want to use a different value for the sleep interval, for example, one minute, run the following command.

trans-unit.source: The client will run until it sees a queue message of "Complete".
trans-unit.target: The client will run until it sees a queue message of "Complete".

trans-unit.source: Note that if you run multiple occurrences of the solver without running the client, you may need to run the client multiple times to completely empty the queue.
trans-unit.target: Note that if you run multiple occurrences of the solver without running the client, you may need to run the client multiple times to completely empty the queue.

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, you can delete the queue and then create it again.
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, you can delete the queue and then create it again.

trans-unit.source: To delete the queue, run the following **TSPSolver** (not **TSPClient**) command.
trans-unit.target: To delete the queue, run the following **TSPSolver** (not **TSPClient**) command.

trans-unit.source: The solver will run until it finishes examining all routes.
trans-unit.target: The solver will run until it finishes examining all routes.

trans-unit.source: How to stop the Java applications
trans-unit.target: How to stop the Java applications

trans-unit.source: For both the solver and client applications, you can press **Ctrl+C** to exit if you want to end prior to normal completion.
trans-unit.target: For both the solver and client applications, you can press **Ctrl+C** to exit if you want to end prior to normal completion.
